4.author: Kiniretrodom5
4.body:
No I wouldn’t agree to any fight being a gimmick. Because the word is overused and meaningless. Radahn, Rykard, Rennala, none of them are gimmick fights. They’re just unique boss fights that have differences between each other and everyone other boss. That’s it. 

“Urm this boss you can summon 6 dudes and it’s a festival and you have to keep getting off your horse, it’s a gimmick for sure! … wait no the fight where that one dude rips a dragons head off, reanimates it and breathes fire through it isn’t a gimmick I swear … noo Maliketh, the only boss who jumps on pillars in his arena, isn’t a gimmick because … I said so?”. 

IN MY OPINION (don’t cry about getting policed) people using that word don’t know what it means and overuse it unnecessarily which is stupid. It’s dumb to say it and I’m bored of boss fights because called gimmicks.

5.author: darkdragncj
5.body:
Wow, did you read any dialog or decide this without playing the game. Enia states, "But the Greater Will has not abandoned the realm, nor the life that inhabits it. So it is that the Tarnished are guided by grace." 

Hhhmmm, sound like the finger readers believe the greater will performs the guidance of grace...

5.author: whereisfishman
5.body: Maybe not physically but it was definitely done with her knowledge and she didn't care to stop it. They are her "unwanted" and are "sacrificed" for it.

5.author: whereisfishman
5.body:
"Ahh, Great Runes are the stuff of demigods: the children of the goddess, Queen Marika. She who is vessel of the Elden Ring. Tainted by the strength of their runes, her children warred, but none could become Elden Lord. And so grace was extended, to your kind, the Tarnished"

Except that is what she actually says.

And your quote also doesn't say that the Greater Will had given grace. Remember the  Finger Readers don't know that Marika is fucking everything up, they think she is a servant of the GW. It is further evidenced by the dialogue she gives you when you need burn the roots:

"Heavens forbid... That is not the domain of mere men.
The burning of the Erdtree is the first cardinal sin.
And you say you seek power of the Rune of Death, too?
The Rune of Death goes by two names; the other is Destined Death.
The forbidden shadow, plucked from the Golden Order upon its creation...
Unleashing the rune now would be unthinkable...
The Fingers would never permit it. Nor would the Greater Will.
... But here we are... The Fingers, dormant, severing our link to the Greater Will.
The realm, and all life, in ruins. Impossible events transpire, beyond the ken of the Fingers.
Who is to say that the cardinal sin must be cardinal forever?
Go on. Finish the job. Take the course you deem most worthy."

The grace still guides you to the Fire giant and the power to burn the roots. The Finger Readers directly tells you that the Greater Will would not permit this.

There is also the opening that tells you she returned grace to the Tarnished to bring them back to the Lands Between. It also tells you it was Marika that took the grace from the Tarnished, with no mention of the GW.

So did *you* read the dialogue?

5.author: darkdragncj
5.body:
I just took the part that was relevant, but the full text if that is what you want. First thing she says to you:

"Look there. The Fingers tremble. To welcome you, shardbearer. Let their wisdom wash over you. "Great Elden Ring, root of the Golden Order. Anchor of all lands, giver of grace, wellspring of all joy. Until it was shattered. The tragic corruption of the Order has taken its toll. Across the realm, life lies in ruin. Fallen to pieces. Foul curses and misery spread, unabating. But the Greater Will has not abandoned the realm, nor the life that inhabits it. So it is that the Tarnished are guided by grace. Called to act. Brave Tarnished, your Great Rune is a handsome  shard of the Elden Ring. Seek another of its kind. To become Elden Lord, and restore the Golden Order". Let the words of the Fingers guide you".


Again, she says the greater will has not abandoned life, so it is that tarnished are guided by grace.

Nothing out of context, nothing up to interpretation. Just outright stated

5.author: whereisfishman
5.body: So where does it say that the Greater Will gives you grace though? It says the Tarnished are guided by grace, which the opening cutscene tells us. I agree there is nothing up for interpretation here, you are making a connection where there isn't one. It certainly doesn't state that grace comes from the Greater Will.

6.author: Life_Temperature795
6.body:
I mean I'm not saying I don't level END above 30, but for a 125 character I'd find it inefficient. I haven't liked relying on poise since it was "working at intended" in DS3, and while that means I occasionally get tripped up in PvP it happens so infrequently that I've never been interested in building a poise-forward character. Maybe I'll start one, just because I haven't done it yet.

And yeah, I get that everything costs something. The guy I was originally replying to didn't seem to think that light roll had a cost. So then I guess I would say that the cost for light roll is probably about the same as the cost for high poise. Either way it's not a prerequisite cost (the way 40 VIG basically is) so if you want to make it you're going to be sacrificing something else, probably in damage.

6.author: GenxDarchi
6.body:
That’s fine. I’m glad you understand. I love this game a lot, so I’m just hoping we get it to a point where everything is viable but not just overtuned. 

I just want to things to be fun to use but not unfun to fight, and the best way to do that is just to talk about it. I appreciate your time, and I’m glad you see my point.

6.author: GenxDarchi
6.body:
I see your point, but you don’t even sacrifice damage, Cipher Pata scales so well you can do near 500 damage with a poke, and 1k with the weapon art. This is while being able to trade with every weapon besides Halbreds, Greatswords, Colossal weapons, Great Hammers etc. 

Anything smaller than a Greatswords you get to passively ignore and just continue swinging. 

Things larger than a Greatswords you can just roll out of their pressure because of the light roll.

6.author: Life_Temperature795
6.body:
Umm... 80 dex and a katana with unsheathe can easily hit 1.2k+. Smaller than a great sword and the AoW comes out *fast.* I'd actually be curious to see how a bog standard dex build fares here, but my underlying point is that I have plenty of characters that are doing that kind of damage in PvP around RL90, so Istill think you're leaving damage on the table.

I do want to try this out now though. I was a strong proponent for leveling vitality in DS3 (the bump it gives you to physical def is MUCH more significant than most people realized) so I would certainly be hypocritical if I didn't at least try a high END light roll PvP build. Personally I don't love the cipher pata, as compared to the coded sword (or whatever it's called) but maybe I'll like it more in PvP?

6.author: GenxDarchi
6.body: Yeah, but that’s a pretty easily telegraphed move to dodge, and with light roll as soon as they sheathe you can just roll back and you’re out of range. Definitely high damage, but pretty easy to dodge. Regardless, high poise with powerstanced pata’s do good damage, have a very fast roll catch, and deal just 200 damage less than an unsheathe while being unblockable.

17.author: IceColdSkimMilk
17.body:
Essentially a proc is when the poison, hemorrhage, Scarlet rot, etc actually happens. When you use weapons that apply a status ailment, you have to build the "invisible meter" on an enemy till the meter is full for it to proc, or take effect.

The higher your arcane, you'll notice that the numbers next to the ailment on the weapon info screen get higher. The higher that number is, the faster it builds up the meter.

24.author: Athmil
24.body:
Arc has three different soft caps. Status effect,casting, and damage.


Damage soft caps at 50 and 80


Casting is 30 and 45


Status effects are 45 and 60

24.author: OkMedium7510
24.body:
Right, I just know after a certain point a lot of people say that it’s pointless/hurts when you go over the cap. (Like Vigor or Str) 

My arc right now is 60. Would I just leave it alone and not upgrade it anymore?

24.author: Athmil
24.body:
It’s not pointless as you will still get more health after 60 vigor and more damage after 80 strength. It’s just that after going over the soft cap you get much less in return and are usually better off investing points elsewhere.



If you have nothing else that you want to level than keep leveling arcane. It will add damage to your incantations just not a lot each level.

31.author: Glintstone-Jedi
31.body:
A little something to keep in mind. You said you're pumping dex. That scales lightning infusions well. Fire infusions can scale off faith or dex, but lightning is just off dex. Lighting is a good infusion, not much resists it. Consider sticking with dex and exploring what keen and lightning weapons can do for you. There's alot of variety in the dex path and some of it hits very hard.

Like, instead of focusing arcane, you can get two katanas that do bleed damage and make them keen with default bleed and instead of focusing on bleed, do a shitload of base damage and then have bleed stack up eventually to like, help.

That's what my strength build does with cestus. It uses the spiked one but its heavy and the ash buffs its damage and moveset and I use rotten wing and millicents to up the damage on repeat attacks and while they technically do bleed, I built them for pure damage.

You can do the same with katanas and dex, and bonus if you keen the weapon you can still put any ash on it \*and use weapon buffs on it.\* 

Depends on how you wanna play it, but you can do alot with dex.

31.author: Glintstone-Jedi
31.body:
Its a very solid setup, the lightning ashes of war actually are also solid, particularly getting honed bolt without a single point invested in faith and having it scale off your dexterity. 

Also the way defenses work you get a bigger boost to damage if you have a weapon infused with a damage type then add more, as opposed to like adding magic damage to a keen weapon with a grease, because the ar is already increased when you split damage to account for splitting it across two defense types. 

So this means like, the lightning strike ash which coats your blade in lightning with a lightning nature put on the weapon to split its damage will see a larger increase than say a keen blade with a magic or lightning grease.

63.body:
Stone is a complete joke in terms of damage and range.

Its really no contest.

63.author: Accomplished-Fix-569
63.body:
One stone - yes, but it is much faster, deals good poise damage and can be chain cast for the barrage of multiple rocks very fast. It is also physical damage and there are less enemies that have high physical resistance as opposed to fire.

So, yeah, there is a contest.

On a pure arcane or strength builds with dragon communion or clawmark seals respectively each stone can deal up to 1100 damage.

63.author: Kalkarak
63.body:
The problem is you are comparing that to a fireball that can easily do over 3k with a much larger aoe, or uncharged for 2k. And whilst I don't know the actual poise values of both spells, I know the only heavy poise damage stone has is against guarding enemies as with its buff in 1.07.

That's ignoring literally everything about range, or the fact that fireball can be boosted as its 100% fire, ignoring free aim tricks and ignoring the aoe. Being able to spam them consecutively only realistically helps in pve due to how easy it is to dodge the rocks, but even then, there are much stronger spells for that purpose.

Its a non-contest to compare the two just due to Elden Ring's mechanics.

70.author: Jordan3Tears

At level 80 I fear you may have developed strength along too far to make proper use of katanas as they scale with Dex primarily, or Arcane in the case of Rivers of Blood or intellect for the Moonveil. 

That all said if you want to run rivers of blood, make arcane your main stat, then dex then str.

For the most part you just want to hit the threshold to properly wield the weapon then pump points into the main scaling stat

71.author: govlum_1996
71.body:
Those are likely to be thorn sorceries, not Deathblight. And thorn sorcerers participated in that war.

Also it is not entirely clear that Godwyn participated in the war against the Giants. The only war that we know for sure that he participated in was the war against the Ancient Dragons.

We know that Godfrey and Marika participated in the war against the Giants. Godfrey led the war, and Marika defeated the Fell God. There is no proof that Godwyn participated at all.

Deathblight was considered heresy. The Golden Order was trying to stamp out the influence of heretical gods. They wouldn’t use Deathblight in a war.

(Edit: Also it could just be that Godfrey uprooted a bunch of trees from the ground and impaled the poor mofos with them. Who knows, really 😂)

80.body: I Just started Ng+1, i have maliketh sword,the Golden alabard and the Fire giant weapon.rn i use the alabard with a strenght base weapons for buff,what weapons do i aim to?

80.author: googlesomethingonce
80.body:
Because there is no boss with high resistance to physical, fire, and holy I would switch between 3 weapons depending on the boss.

Blasphemous Blade is my default, it is arguably the best str/faith weapon. Use this for fire damage. Buff with Golden Vow and Fire Grant me Strength.

I suggested Magma Wyrm Scalesword because it is a good mid-level sword, but could easily be used in the late game and farther.

If they are undead/weak to holy, use Gargoyle Blackblade or Maliketh Death Blade. Maliketh has better scaling, but Blackblade has arguably a more practical skill.

For physical you have a lot of options, I like Gargoyle Greataxe or Gargoyle Greatsword, but it's your preference. 

If you want to Dual Wield...

For Fire damage go Blasphemous with Gargoyle Greatsword and change the Gargoyle affinity to Flame.

For Holy use Gargoyle Blackblade and Ordovis Greatsword.

Or Dual Wield Maliketh Death Blade now that you're on +1.

82.author: JBCKB
82.body:
Well, I must specify my way of playing video games: I play sporadically and several games at the same time. A game like Elden Ringer takes me a year or two to finish, because I don't have time to finish it in a week or two. I can have a week, a month, between two sessions.

Quest log is the wrong term, I'm thinking more of a journal like Baldur's Gate 1 (classic edition): a journal of what the hero has done, not what he has to do. Not much detail or information needed, just notes on some conversations and observations.

As I said, if I played consistently and focused for a few weeks there would be no problems, but my way of doing things is not suited to such a game, and unfortunately I don't think I'm absolutely alone in this case. We can't all spend a hundred hours on a game continuously.

I don't think adding a journal, I'm absolutely not talking about quest markers or anything here, would have broken the immersion or the need to think about what to do, the need to observe the environment etc

82.author: JBCKB
82.body: I don't think of a quest log with quest marker or progress indications, but more of a journal of what we have already done.

82.author: JBCKB
82.body:
As I say in a new comment, I was thinking less of a questlog than of a Baldur's Gate 1 style journal as you say.

People are complaining and being superior when 90% of them know very well that they have used a guide here and there to advance in a quest, including when playing continuously.

I'm not even there, I'm not attached to doing all the quests, completing the game at 100% etc.

Simply, with such a game design, when we regularly leave the game aside for a while, we restart a game and we say to ourselves: "ok, where was I again?", and there is nothing for us get back on track a bit.

You have to take some time to get started, possibly read a guide to remember two or three things, and it's sometimes demotivating.

I've never had this problem with any Souls, and that's what makes me think that the design of these games isn't fully open-world friendly.

You can only parry two specific attacks where his sword has a vivid golden shine to it. It stuns him almost the same amount of time Margit shackle stuns Morgott/Margit. 

Imo it’s completely useless to most of the playerbase because parrying isn’t exactly the easiest mechanic to use especially on a boss like maliketh. The summon AI just targets anything, so if there are enemies out of the door they might target them, yeah. Not a glitch.

Try running further into the room and summoning on the other side, or otherwise just clear the enemies at the door before you go in

86.author: alpha__omicron
86.body:
Oh, I beat the boss first go around but isn't the issue. I totally wasn't expecting the summons to be attracted to something on the other side of the blocked doorway. I certainly can't hit anything on the other side, so to me, it seems like a glitch. Why would your summons be attracted to something that cannot be killed or reached?

I get it. This is a Souls open world and it is supposed to be difficult. I don't mind that part.

I have created several character builds and this is the first time I have seen this particular scenario. I just think that if an enemy is beyond receiving damage, my summons AI should be smart enough to not get attracted to it.

Thanks for the reply #Gasarocky.
